Alia Fierro

Description

Today, we’ll be joined by Alia Fierro who is Director of Housing, Community Development, and Insurance Policy at the House Committee on Financial Services. Alia received a Bachelor’s degree in Latin American and Caribbean Studies (minor in Urban Planning) at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and a Master of Regional Planning degree from Cornell University. Before joining the House Financial Services Committee, Alia worked in housing advocacy with the National Fair Housing Alliance.

Role of the House Financial Services Committee:

The House Financial Services Committee has jurisdiction over issues pertaining to the economy, the banking system, housing, insurance, and securities and exchanges. Additionally, the Committee also has jurisdiction over monetary policy, international finance, international monetary organizations, and efforts to combat terrorist financing.

The Committee oversees the Nation’s economy through its oversight of the Federal Reserve Board and individual reserve banks, the Treasury, the production and distribution of currency, and the Nation’s capital markets.

Agencies under oversight by the Committee include: the Federal Reserve, Treasury, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the National Credit Union Administration, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Federal Housing Finance Agency, and the Export-Import Bank.

Additional Resources

These resources include some follow-up notes shared by Alia Fierro following our conversation today:

  • Urban Institute, By 2040, the US Will Experience Modest Homeownership Declines. But for Black Households, the Impact Will Be Dramatic. (Jan. 21, 2021).
  • Federal Reserve, Survey of Consumer Finances (2019).

    • Shows homeowners hold 40 times the net worth of that of renters. 

      • Backed by a more recent survey conducted by the National Association of Realtors here.

    • Shows White families had a median net worth of $188,200, which was over 7 times that of the median net worth of Black families ($24,100) and over 5 times that of the median net worth of Latinx families ($36,100).

HFSC-Dem hearings that we held late last Congress that students may find interesting (with lots of stats in the hearing memos). 

  • House Financial Services Committee, Boom and Bust: The Need for Bold Investments in Fair and Affordable Housing to Combat Inflation (Dec. 1, 2022).

  • House Financial Services Committee, Persistent Poverty in America: Addressing Chronic Disinvestment in Colonias, the Southern Black Belt, and the U.S. Territories (Nov. 15, 2022).

  • House Financial Services Committee, Where Have All the Houses Gone? Private Equity, Single Family Rentals, and America's Neighborhoods (Jun. 28, 2022).

Information on the housing title of the Build Back Better Act here. 

  • This title has since been reintroduced by the Ranking Member as the “Housing Crisis Response Act of 2023” (fact sheet, stats, and bill text here).

  • HUDUSER: Shared Equity Ownership

  • Federal Fair Housing Act

  • Census Household PULSE - Measuring Household Experiences During the Coronavirus Pandemic

  • Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA)

  • Dodd-Frank Act

  • NAREB - National Association of Real Estate Brokers

  • NAREB, State of Housing in Black America Report (2022)

  • NAHREP - National Association of Hispanic Real Estate Professionals

  • NAHREP, State of Hispanic Homeownership Report (2022).

    • “Hispanic Wealth Disparity Timeline” (picture attached) - at the time that this came out (2019, I believe), NAHREP projected that it would not be until 2097 that Hispanics would reach parity with 2013 levels of White wealth...I am sure this is a much more stark projection today.

  • HUD Certified Housing Counselors

  • House Committee on Financial Services Bills and Reports
